results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 33]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film introduces the third Wootton child. Of particular note are the examples of hand made and hand knitted clothing worn by the children.

Selected highlights list:
(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:14:00:00 introduction of a third child to the Wootton family, with the three children sitting in the garden on the outdoor cane chairs very typical of the era; the older two children are showing their growing confidence in front of the camera.

00:02:11:00 we see a shot of the family in formal clothes , typical of the ‘Sunday best’ way of dressing and posing for photographs at the time.

00:02:40:00 to 00:02:59:00 shows the now toddler’s first steps to confident running around the lawn.

results.title: Victoria : The First 150 Years
results.creator_credit: Gas and Fuel Corporation of Victoria
results.brief_description: An overview of Victoria covering its history, culture and landscape. Gold, sport, bushfires and rural Victoria are amongst the subjects covered and there is also a significant use of historical film footage in this description of Victoria.
results.description: An overview of Victoria covering its history, culture and landscape. Gold, sport, bushfires and rural Victoria are amongst the subjects covered and there is also a significant use of historical film footage in this description of Victoria.

results.title: Punching keys
results.creator_credit: Sally Ingleton and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: A biting dramatisation of the effects of the new technology in deskilling the female office workforce, alienating women from the products of their labour, and rendering them replaceable by cheaper labour overseas. Cast includes a young Gina Riley.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows the family at a number of motor sports events held 1957 - 1959 at Templestowe, Albert Park and Phillip Island.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:10:00 to 00:02:30:00 shows the ‘25th Templestowe Hill Climb’ held Sunday, September 1st, 1957 (as we see from a program for the event that is being held in front of the camera.) The Templestowe Hill Climb was an annual car racing event held by the Victorian Sporting Car Club Ltd. on a 969 metre course constructed by the Club in 1951. The footage shows ordinary street cars participating as well as racing cars. There are close-ups of cars and their drivers and ‘action’ footage of cars driving the course.

00:02:31:00 we see program for the ‘33rd Templestowe Hill Climb’, Sunday, 22nd March 1959, tucked under the windscreen-wiper of a car. This is followed by footage of the 1959 event, which includes shots of the family and close-ups of the children.

00:05:30:00 racing car driver Stirling Moss signing autographs for the crowd that surrounds him.

00:09:06:00 - 00:09:18:00 we see close-up footage of the family having a picnic Albert Park Lake (Melbourne).

00:09:19:00 we see a program for the ‘Second Day: 24th March 1957, Victorian Trophy Race, Organised by the Light Car Club of Australia’ being held in front of the camera. The Light Car Club of Australia held motor races at Albert Park in between 1953 and 1958.

00:10:11:00 we see a poster for ‘The Argus International Motor Races Australian Grand Prix organised by the Light Car Club of Australia’, followed by footage of what appears to be the same event.

00:12:12:00 there is a brief shot of Albert Park Lake with Government House visible in the background.

00:12:16:00 a close-up of the family children transitions to a shot of the young son in a very similar pose at a slightly older age.

00:13:27:00 a programme issued by the Phillip Island Auto Racing Club is held in front of the camera, displaying the title ‘P.I.A.R.C. October Meeting Sunday, 27th October, 1957’. We then see the family picnicking at the event, and other spectators and parked cars, with Westernport Bay in the background. The reel ends with footage of the Phillip Island coast and racetrack.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 32]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film captures the wedding of the filmmaker’s daughter, Bettye Rankine to Robert (Bob) Wootton, both of whom would feature in Kenneth’s films. Of particular note are the opening sequences of the reel which show Kenneth’s interest in devising creative and clever titles. Kenneth frames shots of the soon to be bride and groom separately against a tree blowing in the breeze on a sunny day, as singles followed by ‘Bettye Rankine and Bob Wootton in Our Wedding’ as the main title. Kenneth also uses his artistic sub-titles to separate sequences in the reel as well as his lingering shots of flowers (a device which he used regularly throughout his films). Highlights of the reel include the 1940s style of wedding and the wedding fashions of the era. Scenes at the wedding reception show some of the customs of day such as drinking an obligatory glass of sherry (usually upon arrival) and hosting the reception in the family home. Footage also includes the couple enjoying life with their first child some time later. The wedding segment ends with the couple shot in the same frame, now together and married as compared to the single shots of the opening title sequences.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:30:00 title cards, ‘Bettye Rankine and Robert Rankine in’ followed by, ‘Our Wedding’ which follow a preliminary sequence of the bride and groom shot individually.

00:00:34:00 scenes showing the preparation for the wedding reflects the more simple style of weddings of the era (late 1940s from the appearance of the car models). Although the wedding dress is of a lustrous satin fabric with a long train, it is a simple design compared to the prevailing current styles and the bride and groom are attended by only one attendant each.

00:01:28:00 shot of the full train of the wedding dress.

00:02:00:00 lovely look at Kenneth and Bettye on way to the car framed in the Rankine family driveway and garden.

00:02:16:00 scene showing the family were in a position to hire a car and chauffeur for the occasion.

00:02:28:00 Bettye Rankine in her wedding veil framed in the car window.

00:03:58:00 scenes at the church include a closeup of the bridal bouquets.

00:04:06:00 we see Mrs Rankine for the first time in a shot with Bettye and Kenneth outside the church.

00:04:55:00 the bridal couple arrive at their table at what seems to be a private home rather than a reception venue.

00:04:59:00 framed shot of guests drinking sherry at the reception.

00:05:20:00 Kenneth shows the bridal party and guests laughing and relaxed and the happy groom kissing the bride.

00:05:45:00 reception scenes give us a glimpse into the prevailing celebratory fashions and customs of the day - suits and hats and the occasional fur.

00:06:56:00 the wedding sequence ends with a formal title card ‘The End’ after we see the couple shot in the same frame, now together as compared to the single shots of the opening title.

00:07:05:00 title ‘And Now Kenneth Robert as Blue Eyes’ begins a sequence about the Wootton’s first child. Kenneth sets up a beginning sequence where we see Bettye and Bob and Mrs Rankine gazing at above at the sky looking (as we realise) for the stork to deliver the baby.

00:07:30:00 Kenneth Robert has arrived and there are lots of shots of him as a very happy baby in the sunny family garden.

00:08:04:00 Kenneth devises some scenes where Bob Wootton is polishing a car that suddenly turns in to a larger car that he then shows off to Mrs Rankine and Bettye. Cars feature in Kenneth’s films including a scene here where he and Bob reverse the wide cars down the narrow driveway which was typical of the house style at the time.

00:12:18:00 a title for the baby at one year old showing height, chest, weight and number of teeth. We immediately see footage of what is likely to be the baby christening at what appears to be a country church.

00:13:15:00 showing us the baby now crawling on a rug in the family garden.

00:14:28:00 the baby is sitting playing with a ‘Kool Mints’ tin, playing with water, clapping with his mother and being tickled; the baby being fed what appears to be sugar on a plastic spoon gripped in his teeth to cover his nose, sitting on his stroller and learning to walk between his parents;

00:17:10:00 the baby walks independently and soon after is tottering around the garden.

00:17:46:00 with another flower to separate scenes, we see the baby sliding around the garden on a spade being held by his father, running with a pull-along toy, riding around on a broom; playing with a balloon that bursts, looking quite confident with the camera, playing with a spinning top.

00:19:37:00 title card for the baby at two which includes height and weight followed by a brief shot of the toddler ending with a final flower.

Kenneth frames shots of the soon to be bride and groom separately against a tree blowing in the breeze on a sunny day, as singles followed by ‘Bettye Rankine and Bob Wootton in Our Wedding’ as the main title. Kenneth also uses his artistic sub-titles to separate sequences in the reel as well as his lingering shots of flowers (a device which he used regularly throughout his films). Highlights of the reel include the 1940s style of wedding and the wedding fashions of the era. Scenes at the wedding reception show some of the customs of day such as drinking an obligatory glass of sherry (usually upon arrival) and hosting the reception in the family home. Footage also includes the couple enjoying life with their first child some time later. The wedding segment ends with the couple shot in the same frame, now together and married as compared to the single shots of the opening title sequences.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:30:00 title cards, ‘Bettye Rankine and Robert Rankine in’ followed by, ‘Our Wedding’ which follow a preliminary sequence of the bride and groom shot individually.

00:00:34:00 scenes showing the preparation for the wedding reflects the more simple style of weddings of the era (late 1940s from the appearance of the car models). Although the wedding dress is of a lustrous satin fabric with a long train, it is a simple design compared to the prevailing current styles and the bride and groom are attended by only one attendant each.

00:01:28:00 shot of the full train of the wedding dress.

00:02:00:00 lovely look at Kenneth and Bettye on way to the car framed in the Rankine family driveway and garden.

00:02:16:00 scene showing the family were in a position to hire a car and chauffeur for the occasion.

00:02:28:00 Bettye Rankine in her wedding veil framed in the car window.

00:03:58:00 scenes at the church include a closeup of the bridal bouquets.

00:04:06:00 we see Mrs Rankine for the first time in a shot with Bettye and Kenneth outside the church.

00:04:55:00 the bridal couple arrive at their table at what seems to be a private home rather than a reception venue.

00:04:59:00 framed shot of guests drinking sherry at the reception.

00:05:20:00 Kenneth shows the bridal party and guests laughing and relaxed and the happy groom kissing the bride.

00:05:45:00 reception scenes give us a glimpse into the prevailing celebratory fashions and customs of the day - suits and hats and the occasional fur.

00:06:56:00 the wedding sequence ends with a formal title card ‘The End’ after we see the couple shot in the same frame, now together as compared to the single shots of the opening title.

00:07:05:00 title ‘And Now Kenneth Robert as Blue Eyes’ begins a sequence about the Wootton’s first child. Kenneth sets up a beginning sequence where we see Bettye and Bob and Mrs Rankine gazing at above at the sky looking (as we realise) for the stork to deliver the baby.

00:07:30:00 Kenneth Robert has arrived and there are lots of shots of him as a very happy baby in the sunny family garden.

00:08:04:00 Kenneth devises some scenes where Bob Wootton is polishing a car that suddenly turns in to a larger car that he then shows off to Mrs Rankine and Bettye. Cars feature in Kenneth’s films including a scene here where he and Bob reverse the wide cars down the narrow driveway which was typical of the house style at the time.

00:12:18:00 a title for the baby at one year old showing height, chest, weight and number of teeth. We immediately see footage of what is likely to be the baby christening at what appears to be a country church.

00:13:15:00 showing us the baby now crawling on a rug in the family garden.

00:14:28:00 the baby is sitting playing with a ‘Kool Mints’ tin, playing with water, clapping with his mother and being tickled; the baby being fed what appears to be sugar on a plastic spoon gripped in his teeth to cover his nose, sitting on his stroller and learning to walk between his parents;

00:17:10:00 the baby walks independently and soon after is tottering around the garden.

00:17:46:00 with another flower to separate scenes, we see the baby sliding around the garden on a spade being held by his father, running with a pull-along toy, riding around on a broom; playing with a balloon that bursts, looking quite confident with the camera, playing with a spinning top.

00:19:37:00 title card for the baby at two which includes height and weight followed by a brief shot of the toddler ending with a final flower.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is comprised of two parts. Firstly, travelling on a road tour through South Gippsland from Wilson’s Promontory to Walhalla, Kenneth shows his appreciation of the Australian countryside as he shows the landscape, forests, shorelines and features around him. At times. Kenneth himself appears in the reel on the other side of camera. When at Wilson’s Promontary the footage indicates the style of camping at the time: individual cabins alongside shared facilities likely to have included bathrooms, kitchen and laundry and recreation rooms. Kenneth also shows the old goldtown of Walhalla with its deserted atmosphere. The last part of the reel shows a waterski regatta and speed boats on Albert Park Lake in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:

(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:00:27:00 distant views and roads on the way though what we will come to know is Gippsland.

00:00:32:00 ‘Wilson’s Promontory’ sign, posted alongside the Darby Bridge, its sign and Bob Wootton standing on the bridge.

00:00:38:00 Kenneth Rankine himself looking out over the Darby River.

00:00:45:00 to 00:01:40:00 views of the sea over low lying hills followed by shots of teatree, country roads leading down to the sea, views of the coastline, rocky hills and flower shots.

00:01:42:00 ‘Tidal River’ camping grounds. Just before departing the Prom, there is a lovely view of what appears to be Norman Bay near Tidal River.

00:02:04:00 a sign for ‘Port Welshpool’ followed by views of an estuary at low tide, several piers and fishing boats.

00:02:36:00 a fisherman appears (as indicated by thigh high galoshes) walking along a pier and chatting to Bob Wootton.

00:03:01:00 a sign for the ‘Balook Private Hotel Excellent Accommodation’.

00:03:28:00 after more hillsides and views we see a sign for ‘Bulga Park Shire of Alberton’ (which existed 1855 to 1994; currently Shire of Wellington).

00:04:28:00 sign for Tarra Valley Park appears. In this footage Kenneth has gone to some trouble to capture the Parks, framing his shots of waterfalls, ferns and trees through bracken fronds, branches or rope walks to create a lush feel.

00:06:32 the Corrigan Suspension (walk) Bridge. Shortly after, we are looking down on the Thomson River. Kenneth includes several shots of bridges including the first from which he takes footage of the river below.

00:07:02:00 perhaps foot bridge evident by the scratched initials on the railing. Rail and road bridges are shot from different angles from 00:06:48 to 00:07:02:00.

00:07:10:00 Walhalla Post Office; some deserted and derelict buildings, a shop sign for ‘Agent of the State Savings Bank Guaranteed by the Government of Victoria’ on the door of a derelict Teashop, the Walhalla Station sign on a building which houses old carts with a shot of ‘1903’ on one of the carts, elaborate stone walls.

00:08:11:00 a working timber mill. There are more shots of overgrown brick remnants of buildings in the steep hillsides, rail tracks and old cars.

00:08:41:00 Bob Wootton works a rail lever to move the old tracks. Kenneth has taken views of the town that reflect the almost abandoned state of Walhalla at the time, following the end of the gold mining boom and after the ‘Black Friday’ bushfires that ravaged the State in 1939.

00:08:54:00 program for the ‘A Speedboat and Water - Ski Regatta assisted by the Sirocco Cherokee and Yarrawonga Water Ski Clubs’, held at Albert Park Lake (Melbourne) in 1956. Footage of speedboat racing on the lake follows.

00:10:21:00 a helicopter is filmed flying and hovering overhead.

00:10:30:00 men water skiing; good examples of male swimming trunks. A largish crowd of onlookers and several lakeside buildings.

00:11:37:00 ski jumps.

00:12:40:00 footage of an early display of kitesurfing.

00:11:37:00 ski jumps.

00:12:40:00 footage of an early display of kitesurfing.

results.title: Skyhooks: the video collection
results.creator_credit: Christina Pozzan, Ray Argall and Musical Films
results.brief_description: Traces the history of Melbourne pop group ‘Skyhooks’ using video clips, concert footage, backstage interviews and segments from Australian television in the 70’s and 80’s. Formed in 1973, Skyhooks quickly acquired popularity amongst youths, while simultaneously arousing controversy in conservative Australia. This compilation tape presents 19 of their songs drawn from concerts, and video clips interspersed with television appearances, newspaper clippings and interviews.

This compilation tape presents 19 of their songs drawn from concerts, and video clips interspersed with television appearances, newspaper clippings and interviews.

results.title: The Destruction of St. Patrick's College 1971
results.brief_description: The old St Patrick’s College was demolished to make way for an ecclesiastic office building. Professor Hartley Gratten, of the University of Texas considers, against the background of the demolition by Whelan the Wrecker, why Australians ignore their national heritage.
results.description: The old St Patrick’s College was demolished to make way for an ecclesiastic office building. Professor Hartley Gratten, of the University of Texas considers, against the background of the demolition by Whelan the Wrecker, why Australians ignore their national heritage.

results.title: Every Inch Australian
results.creator_credit: Roland Litchfield, Litchfield Films and ACTIL
results.brief_description: Gives a complete picture of processes used in the manufacture of cotton sheeting at the Actil plant at Woodville, South Australia. Emphasis is placed on the scientific control and checking of all production processes from the arrival of bales of raw cotton to the final packing of Actil products and their despatch to all parts of Australia.
results.description: Gives a complete picture of processes used in the manufacture of cotton sheeting at the Actil plant at Woodville, South Australia. Emphasis is placed on the scientific control and checking of all production processes from the arrival of bales of raw cotton to the final packing of Actil products and their despatch to all parts of Australia.

results.title: A Moving Picture
results.creator_credit: John M. Bale and Tasfilm Productions
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the operation of air, sea, road and rail services in Tasmania, the important part they play in the State’s economy and the use made of them by local industries.
results.description: Demonstrates the operation of air, sea, road and rail services in Tasmania, the important part they play in the State’s economy and the use made of them by local industries.
